channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HIVE-6469] skipTrash option in hive command line
item.description:
Th current behavior of hive metastore during a "drop table <table_name>" command is to delete the data from HDFS warehouse and put it into Trash.

Currently there is no way to provide a flag to tell the warehouse to skip trash while deleting table data.

This ticket is to add skipTrash configuration "hive.warehouse.data.skipTrash" , which when set to true, will skipTrash while dropping table data from hdfs warehouse. This will be set to false by default to keep current behavior.

This would be good feature to add, so that an admin of the cluster can specify when not to put data into the trash directory (eg. in a dev environment) and thus not to fill hdfs space instead of relying on trash interval and policy configuration to take care of disk filling issue.
item.summary: skipTrash option in hive command line

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: It might be better and easier to provide a global configuration property for this. If any HiveSever2 instance doesn't want to keep it in trash, than turn the flag on.
That could be one way to provide these functionality, but having a command line option gives more flexibility and prevent from accidentally misusing it.

Hi Xuefu! Thanks for your comment. Are you suggesting an additional global configuration or to replace the current per command configuration? I would think that users should be able to disable skipTrash if they want their dropped tables to indeed go to trash. Would your suggested global configuration override that?

Actually I was thinking of a global admin configuration, which, if turned on by the admin, will skip this trashing process. I understand the flexibility aspect, but It's hard for me to image why an individual user would care or need to control this.

Hi Xuefu,
This feature typically required to be used on ad-hoc basis rather than globally applied to all drop operation.
2 of our primary customers specifically has asked for this feature. they want to use this for dev environment users where they can specifically mention
to skip trash, but not for production environment users.

Also some people may find this useful
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16301558/how-to-skip-trash-while-dropping-partition-from-managed-tables-using-alter-drop
http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/hive-user/201212.mbox/%3CCAENxBwz6ngo_jvkdAg6D2uLDbgtOn=vJ9KCsgZiN0tMJB0KBfg@mail.gmail.com%3E
http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/hive-dev/201311.mbox/%3CCAORpBshjAQwKUtRMMpKepvR49iRkj=HO9jn0L1BpY=06oACKzA@mail.gmail.com%3E

Jayesh It seems to me that global config is exactly what you need. You have dev and prod envs. So turn on this flag on in dev env while keeping it off for the prod env. Dev/prod should have different HS2 instances. Did I miss anything?

There may be multiple users in each of those environments. So unless we have an isolated "environment" for each user (which is really unmanageable) the global settings for one user will affect other users using the same environment. What you are suggesting is much coarser granularity and would be ops nightmare if I am understanding your solution.

The use case that is being targeted here is that a user may on 1 instance choose to drop a (possibly big) table without sending it to Trash to avoid filling up her/his quota. We believe that the default Hive behavior of sending to Trash should be maintained (to prevent accidental data loss).

It might be worthwhile to be consistent with underlying Hadoop philosophy where users wanting to get rid of data (via 'hdfs dfs -rm') can choose whether or not to permanently remove that data (with a '-skipTrash') option. You could make all the same arguments about individual users caring/not caring about controlling this behavior for that case too.

Do you see any of your customers asking for the global config rather than on-demand flag? Perhaps that can be a separate JIRA?

My argument is that the feature is more suitable for per env rather than per user. I don't understand the argument that a configuration property creates a nightmare for the admin. It's very normal for an admin to configure dev env differently from prod env. From what you described, i don't see why this isn't sufficient. HS2 instance supports multiple users. I'd image that you can have a HS2 instance for all dev users, and another for all prod users.

What I'd like to avoid is to pollute the SQL syntax for something majority of Hive users really need. If the configuration approach isn't sufficient, I'd think that's more a problem of IT infrastructure. Nevertheless, HDFS commands are there to clean up the trash folder.

Perhaps I am not understanding your solution in that case. I detailed our use case:

The use case that is being targeted here is that a user may on 1 instance choose to drop a (possibly big) table without sending it to Trash to avoid filling up her/his quota. We believe that the default Hive behavior of sending to Trash should be maintained (to prevent accidental data loss).

Could you please guide me on how the global environment variable might be used to enable this?

Here is the recap of what I have said above.

Putting data for a dropped data in the .trash folder is a safety feature. It's understandable that in dev env user might want to turn this off. Thus, I suggest we put a server configuration for that. This safety feature is a server behavior, and being applied to tables does NOT mean that we need to provide an option at table level, which appears to me an over-kill.

If the feature is desirable for production and optional for development, I don't understand why a user would want to turn this feature on in an environment while wanting to skip this for some tables. If instead there is such a rare need for this, then manual deleting the data after dropping a table seems more reasonable to me. Thus, I'm not convinced that such a requirement is strong enough to have such a skiptrash syntax in drop table command.

Xuefu,

This is really miner convenient feature which definitely has a use-case for our enterprise customer.
are you suggesting providing this feature via hive configuration that works in following way ?

set hive.warehouse.data.skipTrash = true – explicitly set
drop table large10TBTable – this will skip trash
drop table anyOtherTable – this will skip trash
set hive.warehouse.data.skipTrash = false – if you forget this, it will skipTrash forever, until corrected.
drop table regularTable – this will start placing data in trash

I believe that approach is not very intuitive and will lead to human error that creates disaster if necessary steps are not done, which ultimately violates hive feature of providing trash as backup.

Also, different environment with different HS2 instance may not be the scenario here. This has proven to be very helpful on same environment by different users.

Also, I dont think this pollute SQL Syntax, think of this as PURGE option in Oracle DB and hence I totally see use it being used by enterprise customer.
http://docs.oracle.com/cd/B19306_01/server.102/b14200/statements_9003.htm

Did you get a chance to look at the links I put earlier, where people seen to be searching for this little convenient feature ?
Also did you get a chance to talk to any customers who would like such feature? Please let us know.

Thanks
Jayesh

set hive.warehouse.data.skipTrash = true – explicitly set
drop table large10TBTable – this will skip trash
drop table anyOtherTable – this will skip trash
set hive.warehouse.data.skipTrash = false – if you forget this, it will skipTrash forever, until corrected.
drop table regularTable – this will start placing data in trash

Actually I mean hive.warehouse.data.skipTrash to be an admin property that normal user will be able to set. Thus, the server will have this either on or off. I expect a prod server will have this on while a dev server will have this off. Isn't this good enough? Setting this on/off based on prod/dev seems more reasonable than on table size. If you are in a dev environment, you just disable the feature and why do you care whether the table is big or small. In a prod environment, on the other hand, everything table is important so the feature should be always on. Anything else I'm missing here?

that normal user will be able to set.

I meant to say that normal user will NOT be able to set.

If a user is willing to commit an optional syntax that does not cause a language ambiguity I think we should allow the user to add the feature.

Rational : currently dfs -rm allows an optional --skip trash. Normal users are able to control if a delete skips trash or not, regardless of how admins set the trash feature.

A natual extension is to extend this functionality to drop table.

Thanks for Chiming in, Edward Capriolo. I didn't mean to block this. My thoughts were: #1 if there were a simpler solution that satisfies majority of use cases; #2, skipTrash seems too implementation-specific and exposing it at syntax level might have cause hiccups down the road. Of course, I'm happy to hear other thoughts from the community.

I agree with Xuefu Zhang in principle. We should be extremely careful about what are we adding in language. skipTrash does sound like too-specific extension which is exposing underlying implementation detail. We should explore alternatives to accomplish desired functionality, even if it turns out to be slightly inconvenient.

Thanks Edward Capriolo and Ashutosh Chauhan for your feedback.

I ll put in "hive.warehouse.data.skipTrash" configuration patch soon.

Hi Xuefu Zhang,
I have uploaded HIVE-6469.1.patch that exposes this functionality by configuration.
Appreciate your guidance and feedback to drive this ticket.

Jayesh Thanks for the patch. It looks good to me. Minor nit: Hive code style expects space between ){ in the following if/else block.


+      if (skipTrash){

+        LOG.info("Not moving"+ f +" to trash due to configuration " +

+          HiveConf.ConfVars.HIVE_WAREHOUSE_DATA_SKIPTRASH + " is set to true.");

+      }else if (hadoopShim.moveToAppropriateTrash(fs, f, conf)) {

Would you mind fixing the format?
sure, updated patch. Thanks!

+1.

There is on more instance at 

 }else if

. I can fix that when I commit this.
BTW, you might want to be included in the contributor list. For that, you can send an email to dev@hive.apache.org. Right now i cannot assign this JIRA under your name.
uploaded HIVE-6469.3.patch with syntax update and emailed dev@hive.apache.org

ATTACHMENT ID: 12642030
Patch committed to trunk. Thanks Jayesh for the contribution.

What user doc does this need, besides adding hive.warehouse.data.skipTrash to the Configuration Properties wikidoc? If it's just an administrative config, it could be mentioned in the Admin Manual's section on Configuration Variables (link below). But if it's also for users, it should be mentioned in the DDL doc's Drop Table section, which includes this sentence and further discussion: "The data is actually moved to the .Trash/Current directory if Trash is configured."

  • Admin Manual – Configuration Variables
  • Language Manual – DDL – Drop Table

Thanks for catching this, Lefty Leverenz. he config property definitely needs documentation. I think this should be an admin configuration. User's DDL documentation should mention how drop table behavior is impacted by this admin property's value. Could you please update the doc and I can give a quick review? Thanks.
That makes sense, okay.
Release 0.14 is a long way off, so I won't document this yet. (Or should it be documented now to let people know there's a patch they could apply before the release?)

Hi!

The patch as it has gone in, doesn't enable our use case that I am reiterating here:

The use case that is being targeted here is that a user may on 1 instance choose to drop a (possibly big) table without sending it to Trash to avoid filling up her/his quota. We believe that the default Hive behavior of sending to Trash should be maintained (to prevent accidental data loss).

This is is because the environment variable is not being communicated from the client to the metastore.

I can sympathize with Xuefu's concern to not pollute SQL syntax. Hence I am going to open a new JIRA for providing that functionality without extending the SQL syntax.
Can folks watching this JIRA please review HIVE-7100 which now has a patch? Would that be an acceptable option instead of this?
This was reverted by HIVE-7289 so no documentation is needed after all.
This has been fixed in 0.14 release. Please open new jira if you see any issues.
